reporting-org.narrative: European Centre for Development Policy Management (ECDPM)

title.narrative: 5. Strengthening African regional responses in monitoring and assessing the APSA’s implementation in the domain of conflict prevention and conflict resolution

description.narrative: This work stream aims to contribute to more effective interventions in conflicts in Africa, contribute to analysis for well-informed peace and security decisions and contribute to better informed and more effective policy debates, both in African and Europe, on peace and security in Africa. Since the establishment of the African Union and the development of the African Peace and Security Architecture (APSA), a comprehensive set of institutions, policies and activities have been deployed to strengthen and improve the responses to African conflicts. The regional economic communities (RECs) and some regional mechanisms (RM) have meanwhile also further expanded their peace and security mechanisms, some of which preceded the AU and the APSA. This multitude of activities and policies has not always taken place on the basis of an efficient division of labour, complementarity and subsidiarity. In recent years, ad-hoc mechanisms have been established outside the APSA structure to respond to urgent peace and security challenges but have compounded the risk for duplication of efforts and sub-optimal interventions in peace and security. The EU-African peace and security partnership will remain pivotal in the years to come but has been fraught with challenges and disagreements both on strategic considerations as well as on direct interventions.The most important desired outcome would be that the EU-Africa partnership on peace and security reflects African perspectives and priorities better; and that African and European perspectives are better understood in the respective policy debates. SECURE's contribution towards this end would undoubtedly involve linkages with SECURE's TOC4 work and collaboration with EEA, AIRD and also Migration teams at ECDPM. More specifically, the ToC aims to contribute to three changes: African policy actors are better informed on the various African and regional peace and security issues and understand the effectiveness and limitations of the various regional and continental peace and security instruments and processes, through the provision of evidence-based analysis of activities under the various regional and continental frameworksAfrican policy actors are better informed of the ramifications and potential effects of European policies and instruments, and intra-European discussions on Europe-Africa relations in the domain of peace and security European policy actors are better informed of the dynamics and functionalities of African peace and security policies and structures (APSA, RECs, AU etc), understand the complexity of peace and security realities in different regions and levels in Africa (eg. Horn of Africa, Sahel, Great Lakes region, North Africa etc), and are exposed to nuanced and timely analyses on various African peace and security issues

description.narrative: Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM assessing the progress made towards the envisaged outcomes in the period: 2017-01-01 - 2018-04-24

title.narrative: Qualitative indicator

comment.narrative: ECDPM reports biennially on its outcomes in a narrative

Outcome narrative: Looking at African responses to conflict under ECDPM’s Security and Resilience programme 1 January 2017 - 24 April 2018 Summary ECDPM’s Security and Resilience programme, through its work stream on ‘African responses to conflict’, has established a growing body of work on responses to conflict and security challenges in Africa’, notably under the African Peace and Security Architecture (APSA). This has resulted in a effective partnership with the Institute for Peace and Security Studies (IPSS), based in Addis Ababa (Ethiopia), and a successful transfer of our knowledge base to the IPSS. Through this work stream, the Security and Resilience programme has also contributed to various other topics, including ‘political economy analysis’ (PEA) of peace and security architectures in regional bodies, and the evaluation of the African Peace Facility (APF), providing a stronger link with the Security and Resilience programme’s other work stream (Promoting integrated EU approaches for more effective crisis response, conflict prevention and peacebuilding in fragile and conflict(-prone) environments). Contributions were also made to the work of the African Institutions programme, looking at the linkages between the APSA and the African Governance Architecture (AGA). Through these various streams of work, the Security and Resilience programme’s visibility and proximity in the African policy environment has grown. The programme has established an effective partnership with the IPSS, grounding our work more prominently between African policy actors and institutions, with growing opportunities to contribute to more inclusive policy dialogues and more informed actors. Establishing more effective partnerships In 2013, the Security and Resilience programme responded to a request by the Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) to contribute to an impact study on the APSA. This followed a request to GIZ by the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) to assess the quality and effectiveness of interventions in conflicts under the APSA through diplomacy, mediation and peace support operations covering the period 2007-2012. APSA impact reports, to which the Security and Resilience programme contributed over 30 country reports and additional deliverables and research, covering the years 2013 to 2016, followed. The Security and Resilience programme responded to this request with a perspective to eventually bring this work into African policy circles, based on its objective to contribute to more inclusive policy dialogue and policy processes on peace and security. This happened a first time during an Open Session of the AU Peace and Security Council in April 2015, when GIZ and the Security and Resilience programme in Addis Ababa jointly presented the indicative findings from the 2013 and 2014 APSA Impact Reports. The findings of the 2015 APSA report were presented jointly with the IPSS during another Open Session in November 2016. The presentations were positively welcomed and further sparked interest in this work within the African Union (AU) and the wider diplomatic community in Addis Ababa, including representatives from the Regional Economic Communities (RECs), the EU delegation and others representatives of international organisations and diplomatic missions. These activities can contribute to better informed public and private actors, notably APSA stakeholders and actors (i.e. AUC, the Peace and Security Council, AU development partners and RECs), by providing an evidence based assessment of the performance of the APSA. Providing public access to this type of information about the AU and REC’s performance in conflict prevention and resolution under the APSA bears the potential to contribute to a gradual institutionalisation of an accountability mechanism for the APSA’s impact. AU and REC representatives have acknowledged the value of this work in helping make the engagement by the AU and RECs in different conflicts in Africa more transparent towards its own political organs as well as the international community financing the APSA. Informing more inclusive policy debates Following up on this positive reception by the AU, REC representatives, and other policy makers in Addis Ababa, exchanges were held in late 2015 between the Security and Resilience programme, GIZ and the IPSS on how to transfer this work to the IPSS. Since 2008, the IPSS has hosted the African Peace and Security Programme (APSP), a joint programme between the AU and the IPSS. Through this programme, IPSS had received a mandate to contribute to the definition of African-centred solutions through training, research and advocacy around African peace and security issues. IPSS is well positioned to help close the gap between knowledge and uptake at the African institutional level about the performance of the APSA. In December 2016, a new two year agreement (2017-2018) was signed between GIZ and the Security and Resilience programme to support the transfer of the APSA impact project to the IPSS. In 2017 and 2018, an ECDPM policy officer joined the IPSS for a four month period to oversee the transfer of the work and build capacity of the APSA research team. These inputs and the joint work with IPSS have contributed to the IPSS being able to deliver on its’ mandate to formulate policy advice around African-centered policy discussions on peace and security. With the transfer of capabilities and of a depository of knowledge on the performance of the APSA to the IPSS, its capacity in policy research on vital aspects of this performance has grown. In turn, this strengthens their credibility and relevance as a policy actor in African arenas where vital matters on the peace and security agenda in Africa (future funding, priorities, relations with RECs and other regional initiatives, strategic partnerships to pursue, etc.) are discussed and decided on. For example, the APSA impact monitoring work has started to inform its various channels of engagement with African partners, for example regular country reports on selected conflicts, its support for chairing member states of the AU Peace and Security Council and its help desk for AU member states; thus contributing to better informed policy actors within more inclusive policy dialogues, hosted and facilitated by the IPSS, with ongoing support by the Security and Resilience programme. The political economy of peace and security in Africa The work under the APSA impact report has also provided the Security and Resilience programme with a point of departure to explore a number of other topics and aspects of the African peace and security agenda. This has included a contribution to the political economy analysis (PEA) of peace and security architectures in several regional economic communities (RECs) and mechanisms in Africa, as part of ECDPM’s PERIA (Political Economy of Regional Integration in Africa’, 2014-2016) and PEDRO (‘Political Economy Dynamics of Regional Organisations’, 2016-ongoing) projects. This resulted in several outputs, including amongst others policy briefs on the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), the International Conference of the Great Lakes Region, the Eastern Africa Standby Force (EASF) and the Southern African Development Community (SADC). While too early to assess the policy impact of these studies, the findings of the studies contributed to the Security and Resilience programme inputs to the evaluation of the African Peace Facility (APF), the EU’s main funding tool for support to the APSA, conducted by ECDPM in 2017. Outreach based on the findings of this evaluation will start in May 2018. While too early to assess the outcomes of this work, ECDPM aims to inform intensifying policy dialogues both in Africa and Europe on the future elements of the strategic partnership between the EU and the African Union regarding the financing and objectives of the joint peace and security agenda within the context of the future negotiations on post-Cotonou, the EU’s new multiannual financial framework, including the proposal for a reformed European Peace Facility. Linkages between the APSA and the African Governance Architecture (AGA) The Security and Resilience programme work on responses to conflict in Africa has allowed the programme to contribute to the work of the Centre’s African Institutions programme on conflict prevention and the linkages between the APSA and the AGA. For example, the Security and Resilience programme contributed to an event in September 2016, on “Why do we need the African Union” held in The Hague, as part of the African Institutions programme’s support to the Representation of The Netherlands to the African Union in Addis Ababa. This policy event was attended by a range of European and African experts and policy makers working on peace and security, justice and migration, with the objective to discuss the growing role of the AU in the global arena and identify options for The Netherlands’ engagement with the AU as part of its new regional strategy. By providing inputs to this debate between a wide range of African and European policy makers and experts, we contributed to a more inclusive dialogue on African and European perspectives, including on peace and security. Colleagues of the Netherlands MoFA were highly appreciative about this event as it deepened their understanding about the African Union and provided relevant background knowledge which enabled them to better engage on African Union policy aspects ahead of taking a seat on the United Nations Security Council. Both Centre programmes produced a discussion paper on the opportunities for strengthening the APSA’s preventive capacity and its linkages with other preventive mechanisms across the continent. Relatedly, the Centre published a paper on on the role of women and mediation within the framework of APSA-AGA linkages from a conflict prevention perspective (December 2017). Given the renewed attention for conflict prevention, including by the new UN Secretary General Guterres, this paper contributed to the ongoing dialogue on the need to invest in conflict prevention by increasing linkages between African peace and security and governance agendas. Gender Over the past two years, efforts have been made to adopt a more gender sensitive lens to conflict analysis as part of the APSA impact report. Explicit attention is given to gender in assessing the interventions in conflicts by the AU and RECs. Our reported lack of participation of women in conflict prevention and conflict management under the APSA stimulated an interest to look more closely at the role of women. This led to the publication of a joint discussion paper with ECDPM’s African Institutions programme on women in mediation and conflict prevention (see above). This paper sparked interested by IPSS with a proposal to present the findings of the paper in an IPSS hosted policy dialogue in May 2018 in Addis Ababa. Emerging findings on gender, and gender policies and frameworks as part of the PEA reports on peace and security have pointed to potential future areas of work for the Security and Resilience programme in the coming years, on gender, peace and security. These are currently being explored through a scoping analysis.
